item.title: Reduce bloat of your Lambdas
item.dc:creator: SÃ©rgio Ramos
item.content:encoded:
With most common JavaScript projects, the bulk of the bundle weight is in the dependencies.

serverless simplifies the creation of Lambdas by interpreting a - simpler than CloudFormation - configuration file and automating the packaging, uploading, and deployment lifecycles of applications. When packaging, it can be smart enough to exclude development dependencies. It is a good start, but itÂ canâ€™t:

  1. identify which files per production dependency are actuallyÂ used;
  2. only bundle the dependencies used by each function.

There is a better, simpler, and faster way though: serverless-plugin-ncc. This plugin goes through each entry point of your functions and sends it to ncc, which bundles them into a single file with only the required code, tree-shaken.

Letâ€™s see it in practice: weâ€™re going to create 3 functions, one for a GraphQL endpoint, a Playground endpoint, and a simpler function to save payloads into an S3Â bucket.

And our serverless config:

As you can see, nothing too fancy: three functions declared each with its route andÂ handler.

Setting package.individually will generate a bundle per each function. We control that by assigning it to the INDIVIDUALLY environment variable. We also control whether serverless-plugin-ncc is active based on the NCC environment variable. For each to be active, the variable value needs to beÂ truthy.

With this setup, we can test different configurations via the serverless cli:

Î» time NODE_ENV=production ./node_modules/.bin/sls package --stage production
16.37s user 4.49s system 100% cpu 20.681 total
Î» ls -lah .serverless
4.7M sls-ncc-example.zip

With a global output and no ncc bundling, packaging takes ~20s and produces a 4.7MBÂ zip.

Hereâ€™s what happens when we run the same code and set individually toÂ true:

Î» time NODE_ENV=production INDIVIDUALLY=1 ./node_modules/.bin/sls package --stage production
54.07s user 9.74s system 145% cpu 43.994 total
Î» ls -lah .serverless
4.7M GraphQL.zip
4.7M Playgroud.zip
4.7M Upload.zip

Because our handlers are small and serverless doesnâ€™t exclude dependencies based on the handler, what we get is practically the same output size for each package. Also, it takes +3x the time it took previously because itâ€™s in practice the same logic but for each functionÂ now.

Now, the excitingÂ test:

Î» time NODE_ENV=production INDIVIDUALLY=1 NCC=1 ./node_modules/.bin/sls package --stage production
9.36s user 0.86s system 129% cpu 7.923 total
Î» ls -lah .serverless
797K GraphQL.zip
5.5K Playgroud.zip
21K  Upload.zip

Not only we reduced our packaging time in at least half, but we also reduced our packages by at leastÂ 6x.

You can check out the full source code of this exampleÂ here.

Reduce bloat of your Lambdas was originally published in YLD Blog on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

item.title: ReactJS Girls: The Conference
item.dc:creator: Raquel Candeias
item.content:encoded:
On May 3rd, we hosted our first ever React.js Girls Conference in London, where 300 React Developers spent their day learning and watching the talks from ten incredible React developers.

The Story

In 2017, React.js Girls meetup was created in London by YLD. A culture of learning is one of the YLDâ€™s biggest missions, where community plays an essential role. Every single person who is a part of our community helps our growth, knowledge and contributes back to the community and to the open-source, massively.

When creating this meetup, our main goal was to offer a safe space to women engineers. React.js Girls is a meetup where we invite experienced as well as first-time speakers, giving them the opportunity to share their experiences and stories in React. The RSVP is open to every developer, but in this meetup, only women will take the stage. Two years after it was created, React.js Girls meetup is active in London, Berlin, and Frankfurt, and the community is stronger thanÂ ever.

The Conference

  • 50% of first-time speakers
  • 105 tickets given to the Community
  • 1,089 TwitterÂ mentions
  • 2,6k people watched the Livestream

After ReactFest and Design Systems London in 2018, React.js Girls was the third non-profit, by the community for the community, a conference organised byÂ YLD.

One of the greatest things about organising the React.js Girls meetups is seeing all the familiar faces along with the new ones, getting together to create this loyal family. Every month, we get to spend a few hours with each other and actually, itâ€™s like one of those family dinners you never want to miss (except in this case the dad jokes are replaced withâ€¦ React.js jokes). For us, this conference needed to happen. We had the dream of hosting a day where we could have everyone who has been attending the meetup and supporting the community in one single place. The dream became a reality on May 3rd when 300 developers joined us, and 11 incredible women got to share their stories, experiences, and journeys.

A huge thank youÂ to:

  • YLD for organising and giving so support to the community
  • Partner Sponsor JP Morgan, and Diversity Sponsors: DAZN, Which?, Bulb, Hive, Sky andÂ Typeform
  • To all our inspiring speakers and the best MC Eve Porcello we could have ever askedÂ for
  • And to you, for supporting the React.js Girls community

May 2ndâ€Šâ€”â€ŠWorkshopÂ day:

Just before the conference, we hosted a workshop day with Eve Porcello, Manjula Dube, and Marta Bondyra, where our attendees got to spend a full day with our workshop leads and learn more about GraphQL, React.js, and its performance.

May 3rdâ€Šâ€”â€ŠConference day:

React.js Girls Conference was one of those events where most of the things that happened cannot be explained; the best example being the opening of the conference by the legendary Eve Porcello. You can watch itÂ here:

Throughout the rest of the day, we had ten talks covering topics such as Design Systems, React Hooks or Flexible components. Watch each talk and find a bit more about the React.js Girls Speakers on the Tech Talks YLD YoutubeÂ channel:

Emma Wedekindâ€Šâ€”â€ŠBuilding a Design System withÂ React

(Twitterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub)

(Twitterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub)

Erin Foxâ€Šâ€”â€ŠStorybook: A React Native LoveÂ Story

(Twitterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub)

Monica Powellâ€Šâ€”â€ŠHow To Automate Your ReactÂ workflow

(Twitterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub)

Marcy Suttonâ€Šâ€”â€ŠEmpathy Driven Developmentâ€Šâ€”â€Ša live accessibility audit withÂ React.js

(Twitterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub)

Carolyn Stranskyâ€Šâ€”â€ŠLife is hard and so is learningÂ GraphQL

(Twitterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub)

Kate Beardâ€Šâ€”â€ŠArchitect Your Culture Like You Architect YourÂ Code

(Twitterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub)

(Twitterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub)

Manjula Dubeâ€Šâ€”â€ŠReact Hooksâ€Šâ€”â€Ša hype driven development inÂ React

(Twitterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub)

Weâ€™re back this November with Design Systems London! Find more details above and apply to speak (CFP is closing 1st September 2019).

See you soonÂ ðŸ‘‹
